text: I was asked about one with AT&T syntax recently too.

elements.text: I was asked about one with AT&T syntax recently too.

text:
I'm my `startup.jl`

```macro cn(ex)
    :(@code_native debuginfo=:none syntax=:intel $ex)
end
```
Saves me some trying.

Intel syntax's biggrst advantage is that address calculations are much nicer to read.
Another nice thing is that it assigns to registers on the left, not the right.

elements.text:
Intel syntax's biggrst advantage is that address calculations are much nicer to read.
Another nice thing is that it assigns to registers on the left, not the right.

text: Wow, that keyword isn't documented :/ sounds like a PR

elements.text: Wow, that keyword isn't documented :/ sounds like a PR

text:
Huh, you're right. It is documented for the function:
```help?> code_native
search: code_native @code_native

  code_native([io=stdout,], f, types; syntax=:att, debuginfo=:default)


  Prints the native assembly instructions generated for running the method matching the given generic function and type signature to io. Switch assembly syntax using syntax symbol parameter set to :att
  for AT&T syntax or :intel for Intel syntax. Keyword argument debuginfo may be one of source (default) or none, to specify the verbosity of code comments.```
But not the macro.

elements.text: Huh, you're right. It is documented for the function:

  for AT&T syntax or :intel for Intel syntax. Keyword argument debuginfo may be one of source (default) or none, to specify the verbosity of code comments.

text: I wonder why att is the default

text: I've only ever heard people complain about att and most seem to prefer intel
